AKesp User Manual Abigail Tyrell 18 May 2022 1 Introduction This package was created to facilitate the development and maintenance of the Alaska Fisheries Science Centers Ecosystem and Socioeconomic Profiles.
1.2 Why is this an R package

1.2 Why is this an R package ESP reports are an ideal use case for automation in Rmarkdown. Once an ESP is established for a stock, it is updated each year with the most recent data. By creating a reproducible workflow in R/Rmarkdown, all that is needed to create a new report is to re-run the report creation function with the most recent data, plus minimal text editing afterwards to finalize the ESP. The output contains all necessary figures and tables and a skeleton outline of text, all compiled in the proper order in a Word document. This workflow drastically reduces the time required to create and update ESPs, as well as reducing the number of opportunities for human error. This package was developed based on this excellent book by Hadley Wickham and Jenny Bryan. Briefly, we tried to: >Do as little as possible by hand. Do as much as possible with functions.

1.3 What does this package do 1.3.1 Create figures and tables This package can quickly generate styled figures and tables based on indicator input data. It is not anticipated that the user will need to edit these figures after creating them, but figures created in R (not created as Rmarkdown outputs) can be edited in R (as outputs are ggplot objects) or saved figures can be edited in an external graphic design software. Tables in the outputted Word document can be edited there. 1.3.2 Create ESP templates and reports This package can create templates for ESP report cards. Up-to-date data is pulled from AKFIN and processed into figures and tables. The text is populated with default information and placeholders. The report is knit to Word, where it can be edited. This package can create templates for partial and full ESP reports. After the user fills out these templates, this package can knit a final Word report, including pulling in figures and tables.
1.4 How to install this R package
1.4 How to install this R package The AKesp package can be installed from GitHub. devtools::install_github("atyrell3/AKesp")
2 How to create reports with this package
2 How to create reports with this package

2.1 ESP report card An ESP report card can be generated from the RMarkdown template in the AKesp package. An indicator table, traffic light figure, and overall score figure will be automatically generated from the ESP data. File paths to images of the conceptual model figure (con_model_path) and Bayesian model figure (bayes_path) must be included, or else a placeholder NOAA logo will be included in their place. You can also include a file path to an image of the stock (stock_image), which will be included on the cover page. All arguments in this function are passed to rmarkdown::render. I strongly suggest using the here package for all file paths. AKesp::render_rpt_card( params = list( esp_data = AKesp::get_esp_data("Alaska Sablefish"), fish = "Sablefish", region = "Alaska", stock_image = here::here("book/images/noaa.jpg"), con_model_path = here::here("book/images/noaa.jpg"), bayes_path = here::here("book/images/noaa.jpg") ) )

2.3 Full and partial ESPs 2.3.1 Create your template The AKesp::create_template function creates an ESP template at the specified path. I strongly suggest using the here package to reference file paths. AKesp::create_template(path = here::here(), type = "full") 2.3.2 Create your content Put all figures in the images folder (.png or .jpeg format) and fill out figure_spreadsheet.csv. Enter figures into the spreadsheet in the order you want them to appear. Put all tables in the tables folder (.csv format) and fill out table_spreadsheet.csv. Enter tables into the spreadsheet in the order you want them to appear. Put all your references in the references_spreadsheet.csv, following the example format. A references.bib file will be created and used to compile your in-text references and literature cited section. Edit ...-esp-text-template.docx (can be done on Google Drive and then downloaded). Remember to follow markdown formatting syntax for tables, figures, and references using keywords from the respective spreadsheets. 2.3.3 Create the ESP Finally, use AKesp::render_esp to generate your ESP from the template content. 2.3.4 Example full ESP After creating a full ESP template, running AKesp::render_esp with the default parameters will produce an example ESP. However, since AKesp needs to be loaded locally, the directory with your ESP template needs to be specified relative to the AKesp folder. Once AKesp can be installed from Github, this will no longer be necessary, and here::here() can be used instead. AKesp::render_esp( dir = here::here(), ref_spreadsheet = here::here("references_spreadsheet.csv"), tab_spreadsheet = here::here("table_spreadsheet.csv"), fig_spreadsheet = here::here("figure_spreadsheet.csv") ) 2.3.5 ESP parameters To see the parameters that can be changed for the ESP: ?AKesp::render_esp()
3 Whats going on behind the scenes?
3 Whats going on behind the scenes?

3.1 Querying data from AKFIN The AKesp package queries ESP data from the AKFIN web server. The ESP data can be used with the functions in this package to make an ESP report, but of course it can also be used for other purposes. See here for documentation of get_esp_data(), the data querying function.
3.2 Functions to create figures and tables

3.2 Functions to create figures and tables After installing the package, you can use the functions to create figures. You can use your own input data, or you can use some of the prior ESP data that is included in the package. When you run these functions locally, it will probably be more helpful to set out = "save" and specify a file name for the plot so that the plots are saved rather than displayed in RStudio. This is because the plots all display a large amount of data that will be very squashed in the RStudio image viewer. You may also need to adjust the width and height options to produce a figure of satisfactory dimensions. 3.2.1 Metrics panel AKesp::esp_metrics( data = AKesp::metric_panel, species = "Sablefish", region = "GOA", approved = TRUE, order = TRUE, out = "ggplot" ) 3.2.2 Correlation matrices dat <- AKesp::get_esp_data("Alaska Sablefish") %>% AKesp::check_data() # add NA columns if any columns are missing AKesp::esp_cor_matrix_long( data = dat, out = "ggplot" ) 3.2.3 Indicator histograms AKesp::esp_hist_long( data = dat, out = "ggplot" ) 3.2.4 Traffic plots Traffic light plots are broken into multiple images, each with 5 plots. AKesp::esp_traffic_long( data = dat, paginate = TRUE, out = "ggplot", silent = TRUE ) 3.2.5 Tables from spreadsheets Tables can be automatically created from the table_spreadsheet.csv and the .csv files in the tables folder. Additionally, the AKesp package can also create some tables that require data analysis. 3.2.6 Traffic light score table A traffic light table can be automatically created from a spreadsheet that has a column for year and a column for each indicator. AKesp::esp_traffic_tab_long( data = dat, year = 2021 ) .tabwid table{ border-collapse:collapse; line-height:1; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; border-width: 0; display: table; margin-top: 3.3 Text templates and .Rmd templates Automated ESP reports are generated with the help of text templates and .Rmd templates. The full and partial ESP workflows allow the user to modify the text templates, but the report card has a set template. Text and .Rmd templates can be found in the inst folder of the package.
3.4 Helper functions Some functions within this package are used behind the scenes to format the data.
3.5 Report rendering functions All four types of ESP reports (full, partial, report card, and one-pager) can be created with a call to a single function.

4 Maintenance and limitations At the moment, column names are hardcoded into nearly all of the functions. That means that this package will only work as long as the input data remains formatted in the same way. If there are changes to AKFIN naming conventions or data structure, this package will fail! Aside from these specific data requirements, this package can be updated by future users as needed. (This should only be done by those who are familiar with both the needs of the ESP reports and tidyverse coding in R.) Simply locate the function that you wish to change, make the changes and test locally, and then push the changes to the github repository.
